hypotheses.hypothesis: You are not using 'preventDefault' API to prevent the default behavior of the submit button.
hypotheses.description: When you use the submit button inside a form, the default behavior is to send the form data to the server and load a new page. However, this may not be the desired behavior, especially in React apps where you want to partially update the page.

evidence.description: The first thing you did was typing in the input box.
The you clicked on the submit button, which triggered a submit event.
However, you did not use the preventDefault API to prevent the default behavior of the submit button. This often happen inside onSubmit event handler inside the form.

steps.description: Start by searching for the onSubmit event handler inside the form inside this file.
Inside the onSubmit event handler, add the preventDefault API to prevent the default behavior of the submit button.
Now, when you click on the submit button, the page will not be reloaded.

links.title: React Official Docs for Handling Events

evidence.description: The user interface removed the current UI elements and waited for the content to be loaded from the server.
The browser sent and received the data from the localhost server. However, this caused the page to reload since the submit behaior was not prevented.
The user interface was forced to render the initial state of the app after the page was reloaded.

hypotheses.hypothesis: You are not using 'preventDefault' API to prevent the default behavior of the submit button.
hypotheses.description: When you use the submit button inside a form, the default behavior is to send the form data to the server and load a new page. However, this may not be the desired behavior, especially in React apps where you want to partially update the page.

evidence.description: The submit event was triggered inside your code after you clicked the submit button.
You typed something in the input field.
The user interface removed the current UI elements and waited for the new UI that will be sent from the server.
In response to the submit event, the browser sent and received the data from the localhost server. However, this caused the page to reload.
The user interface was forced to render the initial state of the app after the page was reloaded.
